t: Numbers 23
Balaam’s First Message
Balaam*p said, “Build me seven altars here, and prepare seven bulls and seven rams for me.”
Balak did as Balaam said, and the two of them offered a bull and a ram on each altar.

Then*p Balaam said to Balak, “Stay here beside your offering while I go aside. Perhaps the Lord*s will come to meet with me. Whatever he reveals to me I will tell you.” Then he went off to a barren height.
God*p met with him, and Balaam said, “I have prepared seven altars, and on each altar I have offered a bull and a ram.”
The*p Lord*s put a word in Balaam’s mouth and said, “Go back to Balak and give him this word.”
So*p he went back to him and found him standing beside his offering, with all the Moabite officials.
Then Balaam spoke his message: “Balak*pn brought me from Aram, the*ld king of Moab from the eastern mountains. ‘Come,’*ln he said, ‘curse Jacob for me; come,*ld denounce Israel.’
How*ln can I curse those*ld whom God has not cursed? How*ln can I denounce those*ld whom the Lord*s has not denounced?
From*ln the rocky peaks I see them, from*ld the heights I view them. I*ln see a people who live apart and*ld do not consider themselves one of the nations.
Who*ln can count the dust of Jacob or*ld number even a fourth of Israel? Let*ln me die the death of the righteous, and*ld may my final end be like theirs!”
Balak*p said to Balaam, “What have you done to me? I brought you to curse my enemies, but you have done nothing but bless them!”
He*p answered, “Must I not speak what the Lord*s puts in my mouth?”
Balaam’s Second Message
Then*p Balak said to him, “Come with me to another place where you can see them; you will not see them all but only the outskirts of their camp. And from there, curse them for me.”
So he took him to the field of Zophim on the top of Pisgah, and there he built seven altars and offered a bull and a ram on each altar.
Balaam*p said to Balak, “Stay here beside your offering while I meet with him over there.”
The*p Lord*s met with Balaam and put a word in his mouth and said, “Go back to Balak and give him this word.”
So*p he went to him and found him standing beside his offering, with the Moabite officials. Balak asked him, “What did the Lord*s say?”
Then*p he spoke his message: “Arise,*pn Balak, and listen; hear*ld me, son of Zippor.
God*ln is not human, that he should lie, not*ld a human being, that he should change his mind. Does*ln he speak and then not act? Does*ld he promise and not fulfill?
I*ln have received a command to bless; he*ld has blessed, and I cannot change it.
“No*pn misfortune is seen in Jacob, no*ld misery observed in Israel. The*ln Lord*s their God is with them; the*ld shout of the King is among them.
God*ln brought them out of Egypt; they*ld have the strength of a wild ox.
There*ln is no divination against Jacob, no*ld evil omens against Israel. It*ln will now be said of Jacob and*ld of Israel, ‘See what God has done!’
The*ln people rise like a lioness; they*ld rouse themselves like a lion that*ln does not rest till it devours its prey and*ld drinks the blood of its victims.”
Then*p Balak said to Balaam, “Neither curse them at all nor bless them at all!”
Balaam*p answered, “Did I not tell you I must do whatever the Lord*s says?”
Balaam’s Third Message
Then*p Balak said to Balaam, “Come, let me take you to another place. Perhaps it will please God to let you curse them for me from there.”
And Balak took Balaam to the top of Peor, overlooking the wasteland.
Balaam*p said, “Build me seven altars here, and prepare seven bulls and seven rams for me.”
Balak did as Balaam had said, and offered a bull and a ram on each altar.
